It is somewhat amusing that your comment here is saying essentially what Trump jr was saying in defense of his father's behavior which the women on the view were pointing out. We all say and do stupid things and learn from them. Of course Trump's comments are often taken completely out of context. I have found countless examples of this. For instance, when Trump pointed out the open corruption in some other countries that happened to have connections to certain female congress members. His 'go back' comment was jumped on by the left and rode like a beaten pony. In fact, his fuller comment was for them to go back to the countries of their birth/origin and fix the mess there (which is far worse than here) and then RETURN to show us how it's done. It wasn't a call to deport them or get rid of them. It was pointing out how they want to play the high minded moralist when it comes to America, while being sentimental towards places that are cesspools of abuse, corruption and bigotry. And his grabbing women by the "#%*&!" comment was a commentary on his experiences with women since becoming rich and famous. They would often throw themselves at him and submit and be completely willing to experience anything in order to be accepted. It certainly was crude and low brow and distasteful. But if you think some women are not that way, then you are living in a dream world. I am not rich and famous, but in my younger days I was very attractive and had way more spending money than my actual needs required. And I was somewhat known in my community. And even I was chased by women who would offer themselves up to me without reservation. It always amazed me that some women were so willing to degrade themselves in such ways. But it was fairly common in my experience. I can only imagine what he experienced from women who fawn over celebrity and money.
You seem like a very reasonable and thoughtful person, which I very much appreciate. I wouldn't call what Joy wore 'black face' in the pejorative sense in which actual black face was used in the past. In fact, if that is black face, then Robert Downy Jr wore black face throughout the movie "Tropical Thunder". No one would call that black face, so why throw the label on what Joy did? But the thing that many on the right get irritated by is the outright hypocrisy of the many on the left. This is a very real problem. I have watched as an interviewer would say, "Let me read you a quote made by the President and get your reaction." They would quote something actually said by President Obama concerning illegal immigration and issues with criminals entering our Southern border, and the left leaning individual would of course say something like, "Well, Trump's a racist. That comment proves it." Yet when they are informed that the quote was actually Obama, they change their tune immediately. Likewise, the detention centers which have received such bad press were mostly in operation and/or were commissioned during Obama's presidency. Yet Trump is to blame. This is simply blind hypocrisy.
I could go on and on with further examples, but one more will make the point. The practice of removing underage individuals from accompanying adults who were found crossing our borders illegally was in place during Obama's presidency. There were good reasons for doing this. It was discovered that many such individuals were victims of human trafficking. They were being used as resources to be essentially sold into servitude or worse. The law that allows this practice was passed by a bipartisan majority in congress. While Obama was in office, no one on the left raised a single protestation. Yet the practice continued under Trump was vilified and called inhuman. The double standard applied is simply ridiculous and absurd.

LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL
THE WHITE HOUSE, November 10, 1999. To the Senate of the United States:
With a view to receiving the advice and consent of the Senate to ratification, I transmit herewith the Treaty Between the United States of America and Ukraine on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters with Annex, signed at Kiev on July 22, 1998. I transmit also, for the information of the Senate, an exchange of notes which was signed on September 30, 1999, which provides for its provisional application, as well as the report of the Department of State with respect to the Treaty.
The Treaty is one of a series of modern mutual legal assistance treaties being negotiated by the United States in order to counter criminal activities more effectively. The Treaty should be an effective tool to assist in the prosecution of a wide variety of crimes, including drug trafficking offenses. The Treaty is self-executing. It provides for a broad range of cooperation in criminal matters. Mutual assistance available under the Treaty includes: taking of testimony or statements of persons; providing documents, records, and articles of evidence; serving documents; locating or identifying per- sons; transferring persons in custody for testimony or other purposes; executing requests for searches and seizures; assisting in proceedings related to restraint, confiscation, forfeiture of assets, restitution, and collection of fines; and any other form of assistance not prohibited by the laws of the requested state.
I recommend that the Senate give early and favorable consideration to the Treaty and give its advice and consent to ratification.
(III)
WILLIAM J. CLINTON.
